column1: Barmbek-Nord  (Northern Barmbek) is a quarter of Hamburg
column3: in the borough of Hamburg-Nord. It is located in the east of Hamburg-Nord
column4: approximately five kilometers from Hamburg city center. Barmbek-Nord is a densely built-up area.

column1: Barmbek-Nord borders the quarters of Ohlsdorf
Barmbek-Nord was farmland until the end of the 19th century. As a workers quarter it was populated mainly in the 1910s and 1920s during the process of industrialization
column2: but also had industrial structures itself. In 1907
column3: the Hamburg-Altonaer Stadt- und Vorortbahn (Hamburg - Altona urban and suburban railway
column4: now incorporated into Hamburg S-Bahn) with the Barmbeck station
column5: now Barmbek station started operation. In Barmbek-Nord the stations of Rübenkamp (1913)
column7: the Hamburger Hochbahn started operating the first part of the Hamburg U-Bahn circle line from Barmbek station via Mundsburg to central station. In 1930 the track to the station of Habichtstraße opened.

column4: was also established. Until the incorporation of neighboring villages Bramfeld and Steilshoop 1937 by the Greater Hamburg Act the present-day quarters of Barmbek-Nord and Dulsberg
column5: which were then still named Barmbeck along with Barmbek-Süd
column6: formed a part of the Hamburger eastern border with Prussia. In 1937
column7: Barmbek-Nord became a part of Hamburg
column8: and has remained that way since. Barmbek-Nord faced major destruction during the Bombing of Hamburg in World War II. In the 1970s and 1980s the quarter underwent economic structural change
column9: parts of the population moving away. Meanwhile it turned from a workers quarter into a more family-friendly environment. To date it is a vivid quarter
column10: especially around Barmbek station and the major shopping street of Fuhlsbüttler Straße.
